prompt: What rule allows us to derive Q from P and (P → Q)?
hint: This is the most basic rule for conditionals - 'affirming the antecedent'.
explanation: Modus Ponens (MP): From P and (P → Q), derive Q. If we have P (the antecedent is true) and P implies Q, then Q must be true. This is the foundation of logical inference.
visual_concept: If it rains (P), the ground gets wet (Q). It's raining (P). Therefore? The ground is wet (Q).
